column1: < 12:00|"before noon"|"He was overjoyed to purge the old man's hearth from bailiffs and brokers
column2: and to hurry back to his Uncle with the good tidings. He was overjoyed to have it all arranged and settled next day before noon; and to sit down at evening in the little back parlour with old Sol and Captain Cuttle; and to see the Instrument-maker already reviving
column3: and hopeful for the future
column4: and feeling that the wooden Midshipman was his own again. But without the least impeachment of his gratitude to Mr Dombey
column5: it must be confessed that Walter was humbled and cast down. It is when our budding hopes are nipped beyond recovery by some rough wind
column6: that we are the most disposed to picture to ourselves what flowers they might have borne
column7: if they had flourished; and now
column8: when Walter found himself cut off from that great Dombey height
column9: by the depth of a new and terrible tumble
column10: and felt that all his old wild fancies had been scattered to the winds in the fall
column11: he began to suspect that they might have led him on to harmless visions of aspiring to Florence in the remote distance of time."|"Dombey and Son"|"Charles Dickens"

column10: 'Gentlemen

column1: ap 06:03|"six three"|"'""Analysis

column1: 10:00|"ten in the morning"|"It was not unpleasant to remember
column3: that Mrs MacStinger resorted to a great distance every Sunday morning

column10: and opened a front parlour for the reception of ladies and gentlemen of the Ranting persuasion
column11: upon whom

column13: the admonitions of the Reverend Melchisedech had produced so powerful an effect
column14: that
column15: in their rapturous performance of a sacred jig

column18: and disabled a mangle belonging to one of the fold."|"Dombey and Son"|"Charles Dickens"

column10: and

column1: 00:00|midnight|"It was a wet night; and the melancholy rain fell pattering and dropping with a weary sound. A sluggish wind was blowing

column6: and ride there on horseback. Now

column1: 02:45|"quarter before three in the morning"|"It happened by evil chance to be one of Mrs MacStinger's great cleaning days. On these occasions
column2: Mrs MacStinger was knocked up by the policeman at a quarter before three in the morning
column3: and rarely such before twelve o'clock next night. The chief object of this institution appeared to be
column4: that Mrs MacStinger should move all the furniture into the back garden at early dawn
column5: walk about the house in pattens all day
column6: and move the furniture back again after dark. These ceremonies greatly fluttered those doves the young MacStingers
column7: who were not only unable at such times to find any resting-place for the soles of their feet
column8: but generally came in for a good deal of pecking from the maternal bird during the progress of the solemnities."|"Dombey and Son"|"Charles Dickens"

column1: ap 06:00|six|"Captain Cuttle
column3: did not turn out so early on the morning after he had seen Sol Gills
column4: through the shop-window
column5: writing in the parlour
column6: with the Midshipman upon the counter
column7: and Rob the Grinder making up his bed below it
column8: but that the clocks struck six as he raised himself on his elbow
column9: and took a survey of his little chamber. The Captain's eyes must have done severe duty
column10: if he usually opened them as wide on awaking as he did that morning; and were but roughly rewarded for their vigilance
column11: if he generally rubbed them half as hard. But the occasion was no common one
column12: for Rob the Grinder had certainly never stood in the doorway of Captain Cuttle's room before
column13: and in it he stood then
column14: panting at the Captain
column15: with a flushed and touzled air of Bed about him
column16: that greatly heightened both his colour and expression."|"Dombey and Son"|"Charles Dickens"

column9: turn-to

column1: 00:00|midnight|"In the silence of night
column2: the Captain packed up his heavier property in a chest
column3: which he locked
column4: intending to leave it there
column5: in all probability for ever

column7: the Captain made a bundle; and disposed his plate about his person
column8: ready for flight. At the hour of midnight
column9: when Brig Place was buried in slumber
column10: and Mrs MacStinger was lulled in sweet oblivion
column11: with her infants around her
column12: the guilty Captain
column13: stealing down on tiptoe

column15: opened the door
column17: and took to his heels"|"Dombey and Son"|"Charles Dickens"

column1: 12:00|noon|"Of Walter she thought often. Ah! how often

column4: even with such experience as hers

column8: that hope was strong yet. Her tears fell frequently for Walter's sufferings; but rarely for his supposed death
column9: and never long."|"Dombey and Son"|"Charles Dickens"

column1: ap 04:00|"four o'clock"|"In Mr Dombey's house
column3: there is great stir and bustle
column4: more especially among the women: not one of whom has had a wink of sleep since four o'clock
column5: and all of whom were fully dressed before six. Mr Towlinson is an object of greater consideration than usual to the housemaid
column6: and the cook says at breakfast time that one wedding makes many
column7: which the housemaid can't believe
column8: and don't think true at all. Mr Towlinson reserves his sentiments on this question; being rendered something gloomy by the engagement of a foreigner with whiskers (Mr Towlinson is whiskerless himself)
column9: who has been hired to accompany the happy pair to Paris
column10: and who is busy packing the new chariot. In respect of this personage
column11: Mr Towlinson admits
column12: presently
column13: that he never knew of any good that ever come of foreigners; and being charged by the ladies with prejudice
column14: says
column15: look at Bonaparte who was at the head of 'em
column16: and see what he was always up to! Which the housemaid says is very true."|"Dombey and Son"|"Charles Dickens"

column12: he looks

column1: 22:00|"ten o'clock at night"|"There is a general delusion likewise
column3: on the subject of time; everybody conceiving that it ought to be

column5: ten o'clock at night
column6: whereas it is not yet three in the afternoon. A shadowy idea of wickedness committed
column7: haunts every individual in the party; and each one secretly thinks the other a companion in guilt
column8: whom it would be agreeable to avoid. No man or woman has the hardihood to hint at the projected visit to the play. Anyone reviving the notion of the ball
column9: would be scouted as a malignant idiot."|"Dombey and Son"|"Charles Dickens"

column3: and naps are not yet over in the kitchen. The hatchments in the dining-room look down on crumbs
column4: dirty plates
column5: spillings of wine
column6: half-thawed ice
column7: stale discoloured heel-taps
column8: scraps of lobster
column9: drumsticks of fowls
column10: and pensive jellies

column12: by this time

column15: at home
column16: that by eight o'clock or so

column18: arriving at that time from the City
column20: with a white waistcoat and a comic song

column1: ap 09:00|"nine o'clock"|"'The second
column2: that you will allow me sometimes
column3: say every Monday morning
column4: at nine o'clock - habit again - I must be businesslike
column5: ' said the gentleman
column6: with a whimsical inclination to quarrel with himself on that head
column7: 'in walking past
column8: to see you at the door or window. I don't ask to come in
column9: as your brother will be gone out at that hour. I don't ask to speak to you. I merely ask to see

column2: when they left the regular streets behind them

column4: lurid and lowering; the bleak wind howled over the open space; all around was black

column1: 00:00|midnight|"There are yielding moments in the lives of the sternest and harshest men
column2: though such men often keep their secret well. The sight ofher in her beauty
column3: almost changed into a woman without his knowledge
column4: may have struck out some such moments even In his life of pride. Some passing thought that he had had a happy home within his reach-had had a household spirit bending at has feet - had overlooked it in his stiffnecked sullen arrogance
column5: and wandered away and lost himself
column6: may have engendered them. Some simple eloquence distinctly heard
column7: though only uttered in her eyes
column8: unconscious that he read them' as'By the death-beds I have tended
column9: by the childhood I have suffered
column10: by our meeting in this dreary house at midnight
column11: by the cry wrung from me in the anguish of my heart
column12: oh
column13: father
column14: turn to me and seek a refuge in my love before it is too late!' may have arrested them. Meaner and lower thoughts
column15: as that his dead boy was now superseded by new ties
column16: and he could forgive the having been supplanted in his affection
column17: may have occasioned them. The mere association of her as an ornament
column18: with all the ornament and pomp about him
column19: may have been sufficient. But as he looked
column21: more and more. As he looked
column22: she became blended with the child he had loved
column23: and he could hardly separate the two. As he looked
column24: he saw her for an instant by a clearer and a brighter light
column25: not bending over that child's pillow as his rival - monstrous thought - but as the spirit of his home
column26: and in the action tending himself no less
column27: as he sat once more with his bowed-down head upon his hand at the foot of the little bed. He felt inclined to speak to her
column28: and call her to him. The words 'Florence
column29: come here!' were rising to his lips - but slowly and with difficulty
column30: they were so very strange - when they were checked and stifled by a footstep on the stair."|"Dombey and Son"|"Charles Dickens"

column1: 15:00|"three o'clock in the afternoon"|"They were assembled in Cleopatra's room The Serpent of old Nile (not to mention her disrespectfully) was reposing on her sofa
column2: sipping her morning chocolate at three o'clock in the afternoon
column3: and Flowers the Maid was fastening on her youthful cuffs and frills
column4: and performing a kind of private coronation ceremony on her
column5: with a peach-coloured velvet bonnet; the artificial roses in which nodded to uncommon advantage
column6: as the palsy trifled with them
column7: like a breeze."|"Dombey and Son"|"Charles Dickens"

column1: 06:00|"six o'clock in the morning"|"From this bed Captain Cuttle daily rose thenceforth
column2: and clapped on his glazed hat at six o'clock in the morning
column3: with the solitary air of Crusoe finishing his toilet with his goat-skin cap; and although his fears of a visitation from the savage tribe
column4: MacStinger
column5: were somewhat cooled
column6: as similar apprehensions on the part of that lone mariner used to be by the lapse of a long interval without any symptoms of the cannibals
column7: he still observed a regular routine of defensive operations
column8: and never encountered a bonnet without previous survey from his castle of retreat. In the meantime (during which he received no call from Mr Toots
column9: who wrote to say he was out of town) his own voice began to have a strange sound in his ears; and he acquired such habits of profound meditation from much polishing and stowing away of the stock
column10: and from much sitting behind the counter reading
column11: or looking out of window
column12: that the red rim made on his forehead by the hard glazed hat
column13: sometimes ached again with excess of reflection."|"Dombey and Son"|"Charles Dickens"

column1: ap 08:00|eight|"The Captain
column3: made preparation of pipes and rum and water
column4: and awaited his visitor in the back parlour. At the hour of eight
column5: a deep lowing
